questions.text: Which of these is NOT a pillar of Object Oriented Programming?
questions.explanation: The four main pillars of OOP are: Encapsulation, Abstraction, Inheritance, and Polymorphism. Compilation is a process, not an OOP concept.
Encapsulation is the bundling of data and methods that operate on that data, and restricting direct access to some of an object's components.

questions.text: Which access modifier provides the most restricted access?
questions.explanation: private provides the most restricted access. Members declared private are accessible only within the class they are declared.

options: Same method name with different parameters
Same method name in parent and child class
questions.explanation: Method overloading is having multiple methods with the same name but different parameters (type, number, or order) in the same class.

options: Creating new classes from existing ones
questions.explanation: Inheritance is a mechanism where a new class (child/derived) is created from an existing class (parent/base), inheriting its properties and behaviors.

questions.text: Which type of inheritance is not supported in Java?
questions.explanation: Java does not support multiple inheritance with classes (a class inheriting from multiple classes) to avoid the diamond problem, but it supports multiple inheritance with interfaces.
questions.hint: Think about Java's class inheritance limitations.

options: A class that cannot be instantiated
A class with only static methods
A class that inherits from multiple classes
questions.explanation: An abstract class is a class that cannot be instantiated and may contain abstract methods (without implementation) that must be implemented by derived classes.

questions.text: What is the difference between abstraction and encapsulation?
options: Abstraction hides complexity, encapsulation hides data
Encapsulation hides complexity, abstraction hides data
questions.explanation: Abstraction focuses on hiding complex implementation details and showing only essential features. Encapsulation focuses on bundling data and methods and restricting access.
questions.hint: Think about what each concept achieves.

options: A special method to destroy objects
A special method to initialize objects
questions.explanation: A constructor is a special method that is automatically called when an object is created. It initializes the object's state.
Yes, a constructor can be private. This is often used in design patterns like Singleton to prevent instantiation from outside the class.

options: Same method name with different parameters
Redefining a parent class method in child class
questions.explanation: Method overriding occurs when a subclass provides a specific implementation of a method that is already defined in its parent class.

questions.text: What is the 'super' keyword used for?
questions.explanation: The 'super' keyword is used to refer to the parent class. It can call parent class constructors, methods, and access parent class fields.

options: A class with only abstract methods
questions.explanation: An interface is a reference type that can contain only constants, method signatures, default methods, static methods, and nested types. It provides a contract that implementing classes must follow.

questions.text: What is the difference between abstract class and interface?
options: Abstract class can have implementation, interface cannot
Interface supports multiple inheritance, abstract class does not
questions.explanation: Abstract classes can have method implementations and fields, while interfaces traditionally couldn't (until Java 8). A class can implement multiple interfaces but extend only one abstract class.
Polymorphism means 'many forms'. It allows methods to do different things based on the object it is acting upon.
Static polymorphism (compile-time polymorphism) is achieved through method overloading. The method to call is determined at compile time.
Dynamic polymorphism (runtime polymorphism) is achieved through method overriding. The method to call is determined at runtime based on the object type.

options: A class that cannot be inherited
A class that cannot have methods
questions.explanation: A final class cannot be extended (inherited). This is useful for creating immutable classes or for security reasons.
The 'this' keyword refers to the current object instance. It's used to differentiate instance variables from local variables when they have the same name.
Composition is a 'has-a' relationship where one class contains an object of another class. It's generally preferred over inheritance for code reuse.
Aggregation is a weak 'has-a' relationship where the child can exist independently of the parent. It represents a whole-part relationship.

options: A class with only one instance
A class that cannot be instantiated
questions.explanation: Singleton pattern ensures a class has only one instance and provides a global point of access to it. It's implemented using a private constructor and a static method.

options: Method that belongs to class, not instance
Method that can access instance variables
questions.explanation: A static method belongs to the class rather than any object instance. It can be called without creating an instance of the class.

options: No, they can only be hidden
questions.explanation: Static methods cannot be overridden because they belong to the class, not instances. They can be hidden in subclasses with a new static method.
questions.hint: Think about class vs instance binding.

questions.text: What is a package in OOP?
questions.explanation: A package is a namespace that organizes a set of related classes and interfaces. It helps prevent naming conflicts and controls access.

questions.text: What is exception handling in OOP?
questions.explanation: Exception handling is the process of responding to exceptional conditions (runtime errors) that require special processing.
Checked exceptions are checked at compile-time. The compiler ensures they are either caught or declared in the method signature.

questions.text: What is a thread in OOP?
questions.explanation: A thread is a lightweight sub-process, the smallest unit of processing. Multithreading allows concurrent execution of two or more parts of a program.
Garbage collection is the automatic process of identifying and freeing memory that is no longer in use by the program.
A method signature consists of the method name and the parameter list (types, order, and number of parameters). Return type and exceptions are not part of the signature.
questions.hint: Think about what uniquely identifies a method.
